message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's HIV and noncompliant antiretroviral therapy put him at risk for opportunistic infections. Violaceous lesions on the skin exam are suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, a common skin manifestation in patients with HIV. Cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy can suggest cytomegalovirus retinitis, ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI can suggest Toxoplasma gondii or cryptococcal meningitis, and ground-glass opacities on chest CT can suggest Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, but none of these options fit the patient's symptoms or risk factors as well as Kaposi sarcoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's HIV status and noncompliance with antiretroviral medication suggest a weakened immune system. Violaceous lesions on the skin are a classic sign of Kaposi sarcoma, which is commonly seen in patients with HIV. Cotton-wool spots can be seen in the eyes in patients with HIV-related retinopathy, but that is not the most likely finding in this patient. Ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI are often seen in patients with HIV-related brain infections such as toxoplasmosis or cryptococcal meningitis, but the patient is not exhibiting any neurological symptoms to suggest this. Ground-glass opacities on chest CT may be seen in patients with HIV-related pneumonia or tuberculosis, but there is no indication of respiratory symptoms or abnormalities on physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s chronic illness and low CD4+ count suggest that he has AIDS. Among the options, violaceous lesions on skin exam are classic Kaposi sarcoma lesions often seen in patients with AIDS. Cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy are associated with hypertension, diabetes, and HIV retinopathy. Ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI and ground-glass opacities on chest CT are not specific to AIDS patients.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. With a CD4 count below 500/mm3, the patient is at risk for developing Kaposi sarcoma, which presents as violaceous skin lesions. Cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy are commonly seen in patients with HIV/AIDS who have cytomegalovirus retinitis. Ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI and ground-glass opacities on chest CT are associated with central nervous system toxoplasmosis and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, respectively, but these conditions are more commonly seen in patients with CD4 counts <200/mm3.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is immunocompromised due to HIV and noncompliance with medication regimen which increases the risk for opportunistic infections. Among the options, only violaceous lesions on skin exam are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma, which is commonly seen in patients with HIV. Cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy are seen in cytomegalovirus retinitis, ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI are seen in toxoplasmosis or brain abscess, and ground-glass opacities on chest CT are seen in Pneumocystis pneumonia, all of which are also seen in immunocompromised patients, but less likely than Kaposi sarcoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A CD4+ T-lymphocyte count below 500 suggests advanced HIV infection. Violaceous lesions on skin exam are a common finding in patients with advanced HIV infection and suggest Kaposi sarcoma. Cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy suggest cytomegalovirus retinitis, ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI suggest cerebral toxoplasmosis, and ground-glass opacities on chest CT suggest Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia, but these findings are more typically seen in patients with CD4+ T-lymphocyte counts below 200.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has HIV and is noncompliant with antiretroviral medication, suggesting a weakened immune system. The CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is lower than normal. Among the options, only violaceous lesions (Kaposi’s sarcoma) are associated with HIV and low CD4+ counts. Cotton-wool spots are associated with hypertension or diabetes, ring-enhancing lesions are associated with brain abscess or tumor, and ground-glass opacities are associated with lung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient appears chronically ill and fatigued, and the low CD4+ count indicates immunodeficiency. Among the options, only violaceous lesions on skin exam are associated with HIV, specifically Kaposi’s sarcoma. Cotton-wool spots are associated with hypertension and diabetes, while ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI and ground-glass opacities on chest CT are associated with other conditions such as tumors or infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's low CD4+ T-lymphocyte count and noncompliance with antiretroviral therapy suggest advanced HIV infection. The most likely finding on skin exam would be violaceous lesions, which are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma. Cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy are seen in patients with HIV-associated microangiopathy. Ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI are seen in patients with CNS toxoplasmosis or CNS lymphoma. Ground-glass opacities on chest CT are seen in patients with Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low CD4+ T-lymphocyte count suggests immunosuppression. Among the options, only violaceous lesions on skin exam suggest Kaposi's sarcoma, which is commonly seen in HIV patients with low CD4+ counts and noncompliance with antiretroviral therapy. Cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy suggest hypertensive retinopathy, ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI suggest central nervous system infections, and ground-glass opacities on chest CT suggest pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.
